title: 109_hr2981
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. Congress finds that approximately 60 percent of Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives live on or near Indian lands with a high unemployment rate. These individuals own over 197,000 businesses, generating more than $34 billion in revenue. The service industry is the largest sector, followed by construction and retail trade. The number of businesses owned by these groups increased by 84 percent from 1992 to 1997. The retail trade industry saw significant growth among businesses owned by Indian tribe members and Alaska Natives, with a 84 percent increase in the number of businesses and a 179 percent growth in gross receipts from 1992 to 1997. The Small Business Development Center program proved cost-effective, generating additional tax revenues of $468 million in 1998, six times the program's cost to the Federal Government. The Small Business Development Center program has been effective in supporting small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians, leading to higher survival rates. Business counseling and technical assistance are crucial on Indian lands where such services are limited. Increased counseling has also been shown to reduce default rates on lending programs. The Act aims to stimulate and foster economic development on Indian lands. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands, foster economic development, assist in creating and expanding small businesses owned by Indian tribe members, provide management and technical assistance, seek advice from Tribal Councils, and ensure full access to business counseling and technical assistance. The Act aims to stimulate economies on Indian lands and provide small business development assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians through the Small Business Development Center program. The Act aims to provide small business development assistance to Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians through the Small Business Development Center program. The Small Business Act is amended to provide an additional grant for Small Business Development Centers in eligible states to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians with small business startups and expansions on Indian lands. The Small Business Act is amended to offer grants for Small Business Development Centers in eligible states to support business startups and expansions for Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians. Eligible states must have a population comprising at least 1 percent of these groups, as per the latest census data. Grant applicants must submit a detailed application outlining their goals and objectives for utilizing the grant funds. The application for Small Business Development Center grants must include information on the applicant's goals, training capabilities for tribal members, site location, funding needs, and consultation with Tribal Councils. The applicant for Small Business Development Center grants must provide details on their funding needs, consultation with Tribal Councils, and compliance with grant requirements. The maximum grant amount is $300,000 per fiscal year, and regulations must be followed after consultation with the Administration's recognized Association. The Administration will issue final regulations for Small Business Development Centers, including standards for educational, technical, and support services, and work plan requirements. The Administration will issue final regulations for Small Business Development Centers, including standards for educational, technical, and support services, and work plan requirements. Definitions for terms like 'Indian lands' are also provided. The term 'Indian tribe' refers to any band, nation, or organized group of Indians in the contiguous United States, including the Metlakatla Indian Community. The term 'Indian tribe member' refers to a member of an Indian tribe, excluding Alaska Natives. The term 'Alaska Native' is defined as per the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term 'Native Hawaiian' is also mentioned. The term 'Native Hawaiian' refers to an individual who is a US citizen and a descendant of the aboriginal people who exercised sovereignty in Hawaii before 1778. The term 'tribal organization' is defined as per the Indian Self-Determination Act. The term 'tribal organization' is defined in the Indian Self-Determination Act. $7,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2006-2008. Funding under this paragraph is in addition to program limitations. Funding under this paragraph is in addition to program limitations and can only be carried out with appropriated funds specifically for this purpose. Section 21(c) of the Small Business Act is amended to require Small Business Development Centers to seek advice from tribal organizations on how to assist Indian tribe members, Alaska Natives, and Native Hawaiians and where to locate satellite centers for assistance.
